case_vignette: A 62-year-old man with well-control   led rosacea, a monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL; stable on no curre   nt therap   y) was seen in the clinic for a full- body skin check. R   esults of his examination were unremarka ble except for the presence of periorbital, yellow-brown plaques with violaceous borders    involving the upper and lower eyelids, bilater ally. There was induration, but no warmth or tenderness, of the periorbital plaques. He first noticed the   se l  esions around the time he was diagnosed with C   LL; initially they were more discrete yello  w papules that developed into plaques over time. They    are comp  letely asymptomatic.
